div1.p: Hench explains that he is trying to get Lazear his share of the credit.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 10, 1940
div1.opener:
Yellow fever
July 10, 1940
General J. R. Kean
2804 II Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am returning herewith the material which you so kindly loaned to me.
The remainder of the material you told me that I might keep, and I kept that
distinctly separate from this material. On the enclosed file of correspondence
between you and Dr. Agramonte, you had marked the word “keep”, but I am sure
that this is a mistake. I should love to have any autographed letters of
Agramonte, Reed, etc. that you should ever discard, but I am sure that you
intended to have me return these letters.

I am finishing a medical paper, and as soon as it is done, I am going
to get at the yellow fever story.

Your anecdote about the efforts of Dr. Poucher to obtain a place on
the Honor Roll of yellow fever experimenters is most amazing. It seems incredible
that such a stupid attempt at misrepresentation should be made by a supposedly
intelligent Congressman.

Within a few days, I hope to send you a list of questions, and will cer-
tainly appreciate your indulgence in answering them, particularly to give me the
story of your understanding that Lazear got deliberate yellow fever. I have al-
ready written General Truby and I sincerely hope that he agrees that at long last,
due justice can be given to Lazear for having deliberate and not accidental yellow
fever. Will it be any trouble for you to try to locate a stenographer? I am sure
that I could locate one for you. I have several medical friends in Washington who
have secretaries. No doubt, they would be willing to earn a little extra money
by helping you in this matter, and you remember that I shall be delighted to pay
the expenses. If you wish me to, I will be delighted to arrange this for you.

Let me again express my sincere appreciation for your great courtesy in
helping me with this fascinating story.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
